Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative proposal to build an online, open-access, searchable, central repository for atmospheric chamber data in the United States called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States). Fundamental data obtained from chamber studies are routinely used as empirical inputs and constraints in atmospheric models. There are nine major U.S. research institutions participating in this project, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). This sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data will synergistically facilitate atmospheric chemistry research in the U.S.

The specific objectives of the project are to (1) provide a searchable public index of the chamber experiments from each participating research group; (2) archive past chamber data from each participating group under their indexed chamber experiment; (3) standardize chamber data reporting formats; (4) provide a uniform template for chamber metadata; and (5) streamline future data submissions. The data products included in ICARUS are: (A) gas phase data that describes the time-resolved profiles of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as gaseous hydrocarbons, oxidized VOCs, oxidants (OH, O3, NO3), NOx, SO2, and other data; (B) particle phase data that describes yields of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) as well as optical properties, composition (detailed molecular and bulk elemental ratios), and chemical functional groups; (C) supporting information such as relative humidity, temperature, and light flux; (D) the experimental notes required to understand the data (such as reaction timing, mixing procedures, seed particle addition, and so on); and (E) vapor and particulate wall deposition rates that are needed to correct chamber data. At the end of the 3-year project, the database will be transitioned to the Data Stewardship Engineering Team at NCAR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project is to create a sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data in the U.S, called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States). A pilot cohort of 13 academic/government research groups was formed as the initial participants, then eventually branch out to accommodate any research group that wishes to store, share, and use atmospheric chemistry chamber data in an openly-accessible way.

As a participating member, we contributed to the development and testing of the database infrastructure, including data and metadata (accompanying supplemental data) formats, open-access software to generate and read ICARUS file formats, a controlled vocabulary list, and a website with upload/download/search capabilities. We have digitalized and uploaded published data from the Georgia Tech Environmental Chamber (GTEC) facility to the ICARUS database. We will continue to upload chamber data to the database in the future.

The research supported by this project contributed to the training of graduate students from the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences. A PhD student was designated as the Data Manager for GTEC and took lead in performing the digitation of Georgia Tech datasets and translation into the ICARUS data format, as well as representing GTEC in regular meetings with Data Managers from other research groups and providing inputs to the ICARUS development throughout the project.

Data products from the project include the ICARUS website (https://icarus.ucdavis.edu/) and the integration of ICARUS with DASH (Digital Asset Services Hub) Repository at NCAR (National Center for Atmospheric Research) (https://dashrepo.ucar.edu/search.html?freeText=icarus).

The ICARUS project makes a significant impact to the electronic infrastructure used for Atmospheric Chemistry research by establishing the first central hub locate, share, and obtain atmospheric chamber datasets in the United States. The data from ICARUS will allow for testing and continued improvement of atmospheric chemistry modeling, allowing for more accurate predictions and assessment of the impacts of air pollutants and climate drivers.


Last Modified: 01/10/2021
Modified by: Nga Lee Ng
